rooms.description: Large north-facing entrance hall with open space, minimalistic design typical of Brutalism. Vastu principles are adhered to by orienting the entrance in a direction that encourages positive energy flow.
Open-plan living room with large windows for natural light and cross-ventilation. Walls made of exposed concrete, reinforcing the Brutalist aesthetic while ensuring ample daylight.
Compact kitchen integrated into the living space. Uses industrial materials and large windows for natural lighting; designed to be functional with a focus on ventilation.
Adjacent dining area with open plan layout that connects seamlessly with the living room. Windows are strategically placed for optimal natural light and airflow in keeping with Vastu principles.
Dedicated space for servant's quarters on the ground floor. Functional design using raw materials common in Brutalist style while maintaining privacy and efficient circulation.

openings.description: Primary entrance located on the north side, aligning with Vastu principles for positive energy flow and natural light.
Large windows across various rooms to maximize natural light and cross-ventilation throughout the property.

rooms.description: Spacious master bedroom with abundant natural light from north-facing windows, enhanced by the Brutalist concrete aesthetic. Includes walk-in closet and en-suite bathroom for privacy.
Secondary bedroom designed to provide a serene living space with ample ventilation and natural light, following Vastu guidelines regarding room orientation.
Additional bedroom featuring similar layout and design principles as Bedroom 2, ensuring consistency in natural light and ventilation across all living spaces.
Shared bathroom facilities integrated into the first floor, designed with functional space management and adherence to building codes and Vastu principles.

openings.description: Balcony attached to the master bedroom for relaxation, providing direct access to natural light and fresh air.
Strategically placed windows throughout the first floor to promote cross-ventilation and maintain a bright living environment.
